projectDesc.p: To the tune “Spring of the Brocade Hall”—"Drooping Hair-Bun" is part of The Global Medieval Sourcebook, a digital compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. This larger project comprises computer-readable transcriptions and/or editions of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century, and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia; accompanied by new English translations; high-resolution digital images of manuscript/early print sources, where available; an apparatus that includes critical introductions, textual notes and annotations; and a flexible user interface with which to navigate these materials.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Spring of the Brocade Hall”—"Drooping Hair-Bun"
Drooping hair-bun, I am too listless to comb it;
Frowning eyebrows, I am too tired to draw them.
In my heart, everything is dim and declining.
I have noticed that recently I have been weary,
My gold-thread gown hangs loose.
I know that this man, frivolous and arrogant at heart,
Mocked me in front of others as if it were nothing.
Suddenly he ignored my flower-like face entirely,
And left me in loneliness like this.
How was his heart not bothered by it?
As usual, he broke his promises.
He indeed deceived me then,
Making me secretly cut off a lock of hair for him.
When I see him return,
I will shut the door of my fragrant chamber.
Wait till he wants
Cloud-and-rain,
I will wrap myself in the embroidered quilt,
Refusing to share joy with him.
When the night is late,
I will ask him slowly,
“From now on, do you dare to be so unreasonable?”
